titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Daniel Rubin Papers TAM.657
titlestmt.author: Collection processed by Heather Mulliner with assistance from Jenny Ambrose

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 228 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript boxes, 13 record cartons, and 6 cassette boxes

did.abstract: Mortimer Daniel Rubin (1931-2015) was a prominent member of the Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA). He held many leadership positions in the Communist Party including National Youth Secretary, National Organizational Secretary, Head of the Department of Economic and Social Rights, and Education Secretary. His papers provide a broad view of Rubin's political life and his work within the Communist Party, documenting how his personal and intellectual life were heavily intertwined with his political activism. They consist of national Communist Party administrative files documenting his leadership position within the Party, including correspondence, meeting minutes, memoranda, bulletins, notes, drafts of essays and official Party statements, educational course outlines, and collected articles and pamphlets. The collection also contains files related to Rubin's split from the CPUSA in 1991 and his involvement in the creation of the Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism. Other files document Rubin's work after he renewed his Communist Party membership in 2000.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact special.collections@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open without restrictions with the exception of box 241, folders 1-3, and box 242, folders 2-8. Access to these folders are restricted until 2068.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Daniel Rubin in 2014; additional materials were purchased from Dorothoy Rubin in 2016. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2014.168 and 2015.010.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Approximately 12 boxes of newspaper clippings files, periodicals, and collected articles were removed from the collection. Clippings were largely from trade publications and held little research value, while publications included copies of Communist Party produced periodicals and publications from related organizations that are already included in the Tamiment Library's serials collections. An additional 14 boxes of books and pamphlets that duplicated materials already in Tamiment's holding were also deaccessioned.
A small amount of financial records and receipts were also removed from the collection. These items contained personal financial information and contained limited research value.

Additionally, several boxes containing printed out emails and online articles related to local New York City politics from the early 2000s were weeded by the archivist and bulk emails from political campaigns and progressive listservs were deaccessioned. Only the emails that documented Rubin's direct involvement with these campaigns were retained. These included emails directly addressed to Rubin, or discussion list conversations in which Rubin participated.

Other materials removed from the collection include duplicate buttons, lapel pins, duplicates audio tapes of the Gus Hall program Update, and an off-air recording of an episode of NPR's All Things Considered.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into five series, which reflect Daniel Rubin's work and leadership roles within the Communist Party of the United States. Materials in Series I-IV are arranged by Communist Party departments: Series I: National Organizational Department, Series II: Youth Commission, Series III: Economic and Social Rights Commission, and Series IV: Education Department, which Rubin led at different times during his membership. Inclusion of materials in these series, however, is not exclusively limited to the years he directed these departments as he contributed to efforts of various departments even when he was not in a leadership position. Series I: National Organizational Department has been further divided into subseries to reflect major functions of the national Party work: Subseries I.A: General Files, Subseries I.B: Clubs and Districts, Subseries I.C: Conventions, Subseries I.D: Elections, and Subseries I.E: National Council and National Committee Meetings. Series V: Post 1991 Spilt, documents Rubin's political work in the years following the major rupture in the Communist Party at the 1991 National Convention.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Mortimer Daniel Rubin (1931-2015) was a prominent member of the Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA). Rubin was born in Philadelphia, PA in 1931. Better known as Daniel Rubin, he was raised in a Jewish, communist household and involved in progressive and communist activism from an early age. In 1947 he joined the Progressive Citizens of America and was founding member of the Young Progressives of America. He attended Swarthmore College where he joined Citizens for a Free City College, as well as American Youth for Democracy, a Communist Party affiliated youth organization. He began law school at University of Pennsylvania in 1953 and in that year became one of three members in the Eastern-Pennsylvania Labor Youth League. Rubin attended his first CPUSA convention in 1956 as a delegate to the 16th National Convention. In that year, he became a board member of the CPUSA's Philadelphia district and the district's Youth Secretary. In 1959 Rubin was elected to the National Committee of the CPUSA and invited to move to New York to become the organization's National Youth Secretary, a position he held until 1964. Rubin became the Party's National Organizational Secretary in 1964, a position he held until 1974. Rubin was deeply involved in CPUSA national work until 1991, serving as head of the Department of Economic and Social Rights from 1974 to 1980, and Educational Director from 1981 to 1992. Following the 1991 National Convention, Rubin and several other prominent members split from the Party and formed the Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism. Rubin renewed his membership with CPUSA in 2000 and remained an active member until his death in 2015. During these years his work focused primarily on club and district organizing in Brooklyn and New York State.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Daniel Rubin Papers; TAM 657; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials in the collection have been rehoused and arranged by the archivist. The bulk of the collection was originally housed in folders created by Rubin. All original folders have been replaced, and many folders with vague or general titles have been modified by the archivist to provide clarity and specificity. Original folder titles have been retained where possible. The collection has been arranged by the archivist to reflect Rubin's involvement with the Communist Party and his leadership roles within the organization.

A portion of this collection was damaged by mold and pests. Several boxes of the mold damaged materials were appraised by the curator and deaccessioned. Records of higher value have been retained, and cleaned by the archivist or a vendor. Cleaned materials that were exposed to pests and mold have been clearly labeled to notify researchers of any potential health hazards.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: This collection contains materials that are closely related to the Communist Party of the United States of America Records (TAM 132). The Daniel Rubin Papers contain organizational files of the Communist Party USA, which he retained as a result of his management of various Party departments.
Many audio tapes in this collection are duplicated in the CPUSA Records (TAM 132), which contain more complete holdings of Communist Party events and meetings recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Daniel Rubin Papers (dated 1940s-2015) provide a broad view of Daniel Rubin's political life and his work within the Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA). Daniel Rubin's papers document how his personal and intellectual life were heavily intertwined with his political activism, and in particular his work for the Party. Most well represented among his papers are files from Rubin's work as National Organizational Secretary and his work with national organizational bodies of the Party such as the National Committee and the National Board. Also well represented in his papers are correspondence, reports, and organizing files related to his leadership of the Youth Commission, the Economic and Social Rights Commission, and the Education Department. The collection also contains files related to Rubin's split from the CPUSA in 1991 and his involvement in the creation of the Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism. Other files document Rubin's work after he renewed his Communist Party membership in 2000. During that time, Rubin worked to strengthen the CPUSA's Brooklyn Club and served as a member of the New York District Executive Committee and the CPUSA National Committee. These materials consist of National Party correspondence, minutes, memoranda, bulletins, notes, drafts of essays and official Party statements, educational course outlines, and collected articles and pamphlets. Rubin was deeply also interested in the history of Judaism and communism, and his papers dated after 1991 include extensive research files on international Jewish issues and the role of Jews in Communist Party.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Daniel Rubin, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

did.unittitle: Series I: Communist Party National Organizational Bureau and Department

physdesc.extent: in 74 manuscript boxes, 9 record cartons, 1 half manuscript box and 6 cassette boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises the bulk of the collection, and documents Rubin's activities as the National Party Secretary. It includes materials related to Rubin's work organizing National Party Conventions, meetings, and general Party correspondence. Included among these materials is Rubin's research and writings for CPUSA pamphlets, periodicals, and reports to which he contributed. Other materials in this series include collected buttons and audio recordings documenting CPUSA lectures, programs, and political campaigns. Materials in this series also document the National Organizational Department's work with club and districts. They include correspondence and memoranda between local clubs and the national office, as well as flyers, agenda, notes, and drafts related to recruitment, planning for courses and seminars, and local meetings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided in to five subseries based on major functions of national Party work. Materials are arranged alphabetically within subseries.

physdesc.extent: in 28 manuscript boxes, 4 record cartons, 1 half manuscript box, and 6 cassette boxes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by topic. Organization Bureau and Organization Department files are maintained in general groupings, which are listed in roughly chronological order. This reflects the order in which Rubin maintained his files, and the loose categorization he used in arranging his files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of general files created as a result of Daniel Rubin's national work for the Communist Party. It includes correspondence, meeting minutes, research files, draft reports, and select administrative files documenting Rubin's work as National Organizational Secretary and his work for national Party departments. Files of particular interest in this subseries include National Organizational Secretary correspondence, Organization Bureau meeting minutes, and Organization Department general files. The Organization Bureau and Organization Department refer to the same department in the Communist Party, and were used interchangeably by Rubin. These files contain Rubin's notes from national department meetings and correspondence between Rubin and Party leaders, the bulk of which are dated between 1970 and 1990.

Collected memorabilia related to Rubin's work in the Communist Party is also included in this subseries. These items include a large collection of political buttons and lapel pins dated from the 1930s to the early 2000s. They touch on a wide array of topics including elections, anti-war and anti-nuclear protests, labor movements, and socialism. Lapel pins feature images of Vladimir Lenin and Karl Marx as well as the insignia of various Communist organizations.

This subseries also contains a significant amount of recordings on audio cassette tapes. Tapes feature lectures, workshops, reports, and conference discussions on topics related to economics, politics, and Party ideology. Speakers featured in these recording include Herbert Aptheker, Arnold Becchetti, Alva Buxenbaum, Gil Green, Gus Hall, Esther Rand, Daniel Rubin, and Henry Winston. Titles for recordings were derived from annotations on the cassettes, and some topics and speakers featured on these recordings are unidentified.

physdesc.extent: in 10 manuscript boxes and 5 record cartons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains files documenting communication between the Communist Party's National Organization Department and local Party districts and clubs. Materials in this subseries include correspondence and statistics related to Party building, publication distribution, and recruitment activities of local Communist Party branches. New York and Eastern Pennsylvania districts are most well represented, and include notes and drafts of regional committee reports, leadership training seminars, and outlines for local workshops.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by topic.

physdesc.extent: in 15 manuscript boxes and 1 record carton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents Communist Party National Conventions, beginning with the 16th National Convention in 1955 and ending with the 25th National Convention in 1991. Other conferences documented in this series include the 1962 Special Convention, the 1982 Extraordinary Conference, the 1989 Ideological Conference, and several other topical conferences. Files on conferences include discussion bulletins, committee reports, draft resolutions, notes and outlines for workshops on various discussion topics, notes from meetings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by convention or conference title.

physdesc.extent: in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 record carton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a small amount of documentation related to elections of Communist Party candidates. The bulk of these materials document the presidential campaigns of Gus Hall and running mate Jarvis Tyner in the 1970s. They include campaign memoranda sent to Party members, correspondence related to ballot petitioning efforts, electorate research, candidate schedules, press releases, and campaign flyers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files on election campaigns are arranged chronologically by election date, and general election files are listed alphabetically by topic.

physdesc.extent: in 11 manuscript boxes, 1 record carton, and 2 cassette boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains minutes, discussion notes and transcripts, agendas, reports, and resolutions from meetings of the national administrative bodies of the Communist Party. National bodies documented in this subseries include the National Board, National Committee, Central Committee, National Council, Political Committee, and Program Committee. In several files the Central Committee and National Council meetings overlap. The Central Committee was the leading body of the Communist Party and responsible for the development of Party policy. The National Council, established in 1972, was created to assist the Central Committee with implementation of Party mobilization. The bulk of Central Committee member served on the National Council and consequently the two bodies held many meetings together. Also included in this subseries are 22 audio recordings from a 1990 Program Committee, which include discussions and reports from the meeting.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by committee name.

Series II: Youth Commission and Youth Organizations

physdesc.extent: in 18 manuscript boxes, 3 record cartons, and 1 cassette box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains flyers, correspondence, agendas, pamphlets, publications, as well as Rubin's notes and drafts, which document his work with the Communist Party's Youth Commission and affiliated youth organizations, including the W.E.B. DuBois Clubs, Labor Youth League, Progressive Youth Organizing Committee, Young Communist League, and Young Workers Liberation League, dated 1940s-1980s. Files related to Rubin's work with youth organizations, notably his work at Swarthmore College and involvement in the American Youth for Democracy (AYD) and Labor Youth League (LYL) predate his membership in the Communist Party. While the AYD and LYL were Communist Party affiliated organizations, Rubin's files on these organizations specifically relate to youth organizing in the Philadelphia area. The bulk of the series document Rubin's work as National Youth Secretary, but also include Youth Commission materials dated after Rubin's work as Youth Secretary. These materials include reports, meeting minutes, outlines, educational guides, and publications related to the Youth Commission and affiliated organization, the Young Communist League and Young Workers Liberation League dated as late as 1990.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this series are arranged alphabetically by organization name and topic.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Daniel Rubin was raised in a communist household and was involved in progressive and communist activism from an early age. In 1947, he joined the Progressive Citizens of America and became a member of the Young Progressives of America. Around the same time, Rubin also joined the Philadelphia-based organization the Citizens for a Free City College, becoming the chair of the Youth Division and joined the Communist Party-affiliated American Youth for Democracy (AYD). As a student at Swarthmore College between 1949 and 1951, Rubin participated in Young Progressive for America political campaigns against McCarthyism, Cold War foreign policy, and segregation. He began law school at University of Pennsylvania in 1953 where he became a founding member of the Eastern Pennsylvania Labor Youth League (LYL). Between 1955 and 1960 Rubin began organizing for the Communist Party's Youth Club in Philadelphia, and served as a delegate to the 16th Convention of the Communist Party in 1956. He became the Party's National Youth Secretary in 1960, a position he held until the end of 1964.

Series III: Economic and Social Rights Commission

physdesc.extent: in 19 manuscript boxes and 2 record cartons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains memos, notes, bulletins, correspondence and resolutions related to Rubin's work as the director of the Economic and Social Rights Commission from 1974-1980. The series largely relates to two major campaigns that the Party supported, the National Coalition to Fight Inflation and Unemployment and the National Coalition for Economic Justice. The series also includes articles, outlines, and research materials on a variety of social issues that were prevalent in the late 1970s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this series are arranged alphabetically by topic.

physdesc.extent: in 34 manuscript boxes, 2 record cartons, and 3 cassette boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes course outlines, research, recruiting material, and coordinating materials for the Communist Party's National Education Department, dated largely during the 1980s. The series includes National Education Department correspondence and administrative files as well as study guides, notes on curriculum, registration files, and lecture notes for National Party Schools and Regional Schools. The series also includes discussion guides, outlines, and lecture notes on topical courses and seminar series, which cover themes like the working class, Marxism, leadership, and the economy.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this series are arranged alphabetically by topic.

Series V: Post-1991 Communist Party Split

physdesc.extent: in 77 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, and 4 cassette boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Daniel Rubin's political work after he split with the CPUSA in 1991. Files from the 1990s largely relate to his organizing work with the Committees of Correspondence (CoC) and include correspondence, flyers and position papers from the organization as well as legal brief and statements from a lawsuit between CoC members and the Communist Party. Papers dated after 2000, largely consist of correspondence, drafts of reports and essays, and collected articles related to Rubin's organizing work for both the CoC and the CPUSA. These materials primarily focus on Brooklyn Clubs and New York State regional organizing. The series includes approximately 1136 digital files related to Rubin's work with the both CPUSA and CoC organizing, dated 2006-2015. Other materials in this series include correspondence and petitions related to development of the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn and resistance to the construction of the Barclay's Center stadium. The series also includes extensive research files on international Jewish issues and the role of Jews in Communist Party.

Born-digital records in this series consist of 3.5 gigabytes of emails, documents, and image files, which document Rubin's continued involvement in the CPUSA and his activism in local New York City politics. These files include drafts of Rubin's 2009 book, Can Capitalism Last: A Marxist Update; outlines, emails, and meeting notes from national, district, and local CPUSA organizing activities; and flyers, correspondence, and photos documenting Rubin's involvement in progressive political campaigns in Brooklyn and New York City. Rubin also saved biographical articles and obituaries honoring prominent Communist Party members. These biographical files include newspaper articles as well as transcripts of speeches honoring deceased Party members that Rubin collected for memorial events, the bulk of which are written about former Communist Party chairman Henry Winston.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files in this series are arranged alphabetically by name of organization and topic.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Daniel Rubin left the Communist Party in 1991 along with many other Party members following political disagreements presented at the Party's 25th National Convention. Dissenting members formed the Committees of Correspondence, which later named the Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism. Beginning in 1992, Rubin and several other former Communist Party members were sued by the Communist Party over the wills of Rachel Freidenberg and Rosalind Tratchenberg who had bequeathed money to individual Party members. Party leadership claimed that money bequeathed by Freidenberg and Tratchenberg were intended for Communist Party and disputed Rubin's and other former member's intention to donate funds to the Committees of Correspondence. The cases were eventually settled in the late 1990s. Rubin renewed his membership in the Communist Party in 2000 and remained an active member in the party until his death in 2015.
